prompt: Write a poem about name badge in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nametaggle

’Twas foyerfall, and lither hosts
did mingle-murmur under lights;
All tackly were the peel-and-posts,
and clipclasped banner-kites.

Beware the Nametaggle, child!
The glue that grips, the font that bites!
Beware the Frumilanyard wild,
and shun the check-in sprites!

He took his Sharpish Marker-sword;
long time the planny foe he sought—
So rested he by coffee-board,
and pondered name and nought.

And, as he sipped his milky brew
and hovered by the swaggy tray,
The Nametaggle hove in view,
with “H’lo-my-name-is” grey.

One, two! One, two! and through and through
the Sharpish nib went snick-snack-snake!
He wrote his name from stem to sprue,
and made the sticker quake.

He pressed it firm upon his vest—
“Ho, hulloh!” all letters shone;
It knew his call, and knew the rest,
and namelessness was gone.

“And hast thou tamed the Taggle, sprout?
Come hither, brave and beaming boy!
O gladgloss day! Hurray! Hurrout!”
So chimed the room with joy.

’Twas foyerfall; the lanyard-lace
did dangle-drift by bustled doors;
The badgebird sang in naméd grace,
and peace lay on the floors.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on bittersweet victory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Glorygloom

It was glimber dusk, and lissome loons
Did flurry-wurl through bristled vale;
All wincey were the bramble-blooms,
And nither-naths told tale.

“Heed thee the Sorrowlox, my sprout—
Its grieving grin, its binding gaze;
Beware the crooning Gloamwing’s snout,
And shun the whisper-maze.”

He fetched his keenling rhyme-edged brand,
Long while he sought the hushwood path;
He stood beside the sablesand,
And mulled his mingled wrath.

And as he mused by murkfen spring,
The Sorrowlox, with muffled cheer,
Came whuffling through the brumble-ring,
Its smile wet with a tear.

Clip-crack! went blade on weeping scale;
Flip-flam! the hollows sung;
He split its sigh, he cleft its wail,
And stilled the grieving tongue.

He bore its burden, limp and low,
Across the thistle lane;
The farbells rang a brittle glow,
And salt was in the rain.

“O glorygloom!” the elder cried,
“Come, timbered child, to me!
Thy deed rings bright, yet shadows bide;
Such wins have thorns, you see.”

It’s glimber dusk; the lissome loons
Still flurry-wurl through bristled vale;
All pensive are the bramble-blooms,
As nither-naths tell tale.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about a promise kept in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Oathquickle

Glimmer was the greel-grale dusk,
and snithy skrints did flindle-keep;
The puddled prills of nettle-musk
lay murmle-mild asleep.

"Mark ye the nickle-nackle clocks,"
quoth Mother Mirl in chimney-glow;
"Hold fast the promise that you spoke,
and bring it back ere snow."

I took my tassled telltale cord,
my wherrish boots, my mittened hand,
and to the nettle-narrow ford
I strode the swoggle land.

The Ficklefen with candle-teeth
went nibble-nabble down the hill;
"Come, break thy vow," it hummed beneath,
"and doze beside my sill."

I knotted tight my telltale cord
and answered with a steadfast no;
I kept my vow while cold-winds gnawed,
and found the ember's glow.

Back through the drindle-drumble night
I ferried home that chiming spark;
"O hurrahday!" she cried outright,
"thy word has lit the dark!"

Now mellow is the greel-grale dusk,
and snithy hearths in comfort sleep;
The promise polished, burnished, brusque—
we warm the words we keep.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about paperclip chain in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Paperclip Chain

It was nickel-noon; the curly-clips
Went flimmer-flam across the grain;
The staplebirds with silver lips
Sang dripple-songs of paper rain.

Oh mind the Paperclip Chain, young sprout—
That linkling snake of deskbound lairs!
It twangles out and twirls about,
It nibbles knots and tangles hairs.

Take up your snip-o-saber keen,
Your unspooler of wiry spiel;
Beware the magnet-marmosheen,
And mind the reels of rolling steel.

He sought it near the blotter wood,
He watched beneath the lampwick light;
He hummed a hum of knuckled good
And eyed the margins, sharp and bright.

And as he mused in swivel-thought,
The Paperclip Chain with chiming jaw
Came clink-a-clank and looping taut
Through staplepines in ledger-draw.

Snip-snap! went shear and shiver-glint;
The cutter flashed its nickel rain;
He bent each kink from curl to flint
And broke the bite of chainy chain.

He straightened links from curl to line,
He soothed the snarl to docile ring;
He taught the thing to thread and shine,
A friendly leash for paperspring.

And hast thou tamed the Chain of Clips?
O gleam-eyed child, now bring it home!
They wound it round their flying slips
And crowned him Lord of Desk and Chrome.

Now nickel-noon is mild and meek;
The curly-clips lie calm again.
The staplebirds in whispers speak
Of brave unknots along the grain.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on control theory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Feedbackwyrm

In dither-hour the servo-sliths
Went gimbal-wobble round the plane;
The bodegrass hissed with phasey myths,
And Laplace brewed the rain.

Mind Overshoot and Hunting-ring,
The limit-cycle’s snare;
Bewatch the Plant-unknowing thing,
And Noisegnats everywhere.

He donned a Kalman lantern-glow
To sift the measurement blurs;
He tuned a PID blade just so,
With anti-windup spurs.

Along the Root-Locusy lane
He paced with LQR poise;
The zeros smirked, the poles slid sane,
Far left from s-plane noise.

And while he traced the Nyquist curl,
The Feedbackwyrm uncoiled;
It phase-lagged forth in hiss and whirl,
With param-gremlins oiled.

Then rose the blade of P and D,
The I kept tight at heel;
He slew the ringy transient spree
And trimmed the settling peal.

The margins fat—both phase and gain—
The rise-time neat and stayed;
The overshoot a tiny grain,
The jitter’s debts all paid.

He bore the tamed error back—
The mentor tapped the trace:
“How stable-brave your track-on-track,
What happy left-half place!”

Oh settled skies, huzza huzay!
Sing, plant and sensor pair!
For Feedbackwyrm is leashed today,
And peace pervades the air.

And now the servo-sliths at rest
Through gimbal-dreams recline;
The loopling world, in closed-loop nest,
Purrs steady, fine, and fine.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about error correction in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Parity Blade

It pingled in the buffer dusk;
The packet-stream went snither-snap;
All flimble lay the header husk,
While checksum-sprites went trap-a-tap.

"Keep watch for Flip-Bit Fuzziwog,
Who gnaws the code with jitter-jaw!
Beware the Frumious Static Fog,
And mind the Lurch of Lost-in-raw!"

He gripped his Hamming-gleaming blade;
Long time the parity foe he sought—
He rested by a Nodey glade
And framed an error-correcting thought.

And, as by Viterbi-vine he stood,
The Burblebit, with ripple-roar,
Came whiffling through the copper wood,
Bit-flipping o'er the backplane floor.

Tick-tack! Bit-clock! clack-clackity clack!
The parity blade made flicker-flack!
He cast a Reed–Solomon charm,
And drove the noise-gnome down the stack.

Then galumphing through the logs and streams,
He stitched the XORs end to end;
He soothed the Levenshteinish dreams,
And hailed his error-fixing friend.

"O bugless sway! Hooray, array!"
They logged his feat in glowing code;
For flips were caught and turned away,
And clean ran all the upload road.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about evening breeze in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Evebreeze

It was the gloam; the willow-limbs
Skursivered along the lane;
All hushsome were the meadow-brims,
And dew-stars prinked the plain.

Outwhist the Evebreeze, whiffer-thin,
Through thistle-thread and barley-gold;
It twanged the gate with fiddlechin
And rimpled hedges old.

It plucked the pond of ripple-runes
Till minnows learned to rhyme;
It rumpled up the ribboned dunes
And skimmed the scarecrow’s time.

I buttoned up my bramble-coat,
Yet let my throat-scarf fly;
It skittle-flicked about my throat—
A purl of lullaby.

O Evebreeze, breezy eve of eves,
You murmur-mend the day;
You leaf the dark in silken sheaves
And waltz the worries away.

You swither through the chimble-stacks,
You shiver through the rye,
You tip the moons on windowbacks
And teach the owls to sigh.

Then softer still, with gloamish grace,
You lull the cricket-chime,
And feather-close each tilted place
Of time within its time.

The gloam goes on; the willow-limbs
Grow still beside the lane;
How dreamsome lie the meadow-brims,
While nightflakes quilt the plain.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on zebra crossing in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Belishabright at the Zebra-Line

'Twas belishabright, and the zebralanes
Did zither-zather stripe the street;
All mimsome massed the kerbside trains,
While motorherds went bleat.

"Beware the Zoomer-cars, my sprout!
Their blareful honks, their glareful eyes!
Bewatch the swervy vans about,
And shun the skitter-bikes that rise!"

He took his Look-Both lore in hand,
And toe-tip stood by gutter's brim;
In huffle-hush across the land
The belishabobs blinked prim.

And as he hove in nervish poise,
The zoomer-cars grew mild and wan;
They murmur-braked their thunder-noise,
And let the footlings on.

Step-clicker-clack through stripe and stripe,
He zedder-zagged the black-and-white;
The pramlets rolled, the dog went yipe,
The rainboots splashed with might.

"O stripesome day! Beloo! Belay!"
He sang across the final line;
He tucked his Look-Both lore away
And felt his toesies shine.

'Twas belishabright, and the zebralanes
Did zither-zather stripe the street;
All oodly good the kerbside trains,
And motorherds went neat.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about moving day in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about burnt toast in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Toastberwocky

'Twas morningtide, and crispy loaves
Did char and chitter in the slots;
All smokesome were the crumby groves,
And toaster-bells outblots.

"Beware the Toastberwock, my child!
The edges char, the smoke that clings!
Beware the butter-gnashers wild,
The poppings, springs, and ding-a-lings!"

He took his silver tongs in hand;
Long time the carbon-crust he sought—
So rested he by kettle-stand,
And thunk a thinksome thought.

And as in amber-musing stood,
The Toastberwock, with sizzle-roar,
Came smokling through the crumbly wood
And gargled, grim, galore.

One-two! One-two! Through-through he flew—
The silver tongs went scritcher-scrack!
He snatched it from the popping brew
And quelled the charcoal-black with whack!

"And hast thou tamed the Toastberwock?
Come to my arms, my crispy joy!
O triumph-morn! Kaloo! Kalock!"
He galumphed, crumb-hoisting boy.

'Twas morningtide, and crispy loaves
Did char and chitter in the slots;
All smokesome were the crumby groves,
And toaster-bells outblots.
label: high
